Respectfully Translated by Imperial Decree Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the perfection of wisdom.
What are the ten?
First, the wisdom of the non-self of persons;
Second, the wisdom of the non-self of dharmas;
Third, the wisdom of having no parts;
Fourth, the wisdom of knowing the definite realm;
Fifth, the wisdom of empowerment;
Sixth, the indestructible wisdom;
Seventh, the wisdom of well observing the practices of all sentient beings;
Eighth, the wisdom of having no enlightenment;
Ninth, the wisdom of well understanding the characteristics of all dharmas;
Tenth, the supramundane wisdom.
What is the wisdom of the non-self of persons?
That is to say, if a bodhisattva observes the arising of the aggregates and the cessation of the aggregates, when the aggregates arise, he observes that phenomena are unreal, false, and not solid;
when the aggregates cease, he observes that phenomena disperse and go nowhere.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

In these aggregates, there is no self, no person, no sentient being, no life, no nourisher, yet foolish ordinary beings are attached to the self and give rise to this thought:ğŸ”½Are the aggregates within the self?
Is the self within the aggregates?ğŸ”½Am I not the aggregates?
Are the aggregates not me?
Because of this attachment, they do not understand the truth, and because of not understanding, they revolve in birth and death like a fire wheel turning.
The bodhisattva fully knows such dharmas as they really are. This is called the bodhisattva's wisdom of no-self in persons.
What is the wisdom of no-self in dharmas?
It means that if a bodhisattva knows the formation and disintegration of all dharmas as they really are,
the bodhisattva thinks like this:

'This is the establishment of discrimination within provisional phenomena, but those phenomena have no real intrinsic nature, and even the letters have no intrinsic nature. It is only the conceptual discrimination of memory and thought, the activity of the conventional world. One should not give rise to attachment to that. However, the conventional borrowing of various phenomena is also not non-existent. It is said that phenomena exist in dependence on conditions. Phenomena arise from conditions and phenomena cease from conditions. The bodhisattva fully understands such phenomena.'
This is the bodhisattva's wisdom of the non-self of phenomena.
What is the wisdom of having no fixed location?

It is said that the wisdom of the bodhisattva has no fixed location. It is not only the case that the wisdom of one instant can follow and turn, and the wisdom of the second instant does not follow and turn.
Why is it so?
The wisdom of the bodhisattva in one instant universally follows and manifests everywhere. This is the bodhisattva's wisdom of having no fixed location.

if the realm of the samÄdhi cultivated by Å›rÄvakas is something a bodhisattva can know, if the realm of the samÄdhi cultivated by pratyekabuddhas is something a bodhisattva can know, if the realm of the samÄdhi cultivated by bodhisattvas is something a bodhisattva can know, if the realm of the samÄdhi practiced by tathÄgatas is something a bodhisattva can also know, then it is not by the power of one's own wisdom that has been accomplished through past karmic retribution that one can understand it.

But it is only because of the power of the TathÄgata's majestic spiritual power that one is able to know it. The other dharmas of samÄdhi can all be understood by one's own wisdom. This is called the bodhisattvas' knowledge of the realm of samÄdhi.
What is the knowledge of empowerment?

It means that if a bodhisattva can know as it is the empowered dharmas possessed by Å›rÄvakas, can know as it is the empowerment of pratyekabuddhas, can know as it is the empowerment of bodhisattvas, then how much more so can he know the empowerments of other sentient beings?
This is called the bodhisattvas' wisdom of empowerment.
What is called indestructible wisdom?

It means that if a bodhisattva attains indestructible wisdom, all mÄras, non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas will be unable to destroy it. This is called the bodhisattvas' indestructible wisdom.
What is called the wisdom that is able to observe the practices of all sentient beings?

It means that if a bodhisattva uses their wisdom that is unattached, uninterrupted, and pure, they can universally observe all sentient beings in the realm of sentient beings and see them all. Some sentient beings give rise to the bodhi mind,
some do not give rise to the bodhi mind, some fulfill the practices of bodhi,
some do not fulfill the practices of bodhi, some abide in the first ground, some abide up to the tenth ground,
some presently attain perfect enlightenment, some, having attained perfect enlightenment, turn the wheel of the Dharma,
some extensively carry out all transformative and beneficial activities and then enter great nirvÄá¹‡a, some enter
Those who enter the Å›rÄvaka vehicle's nirvÄá¹‡a, those who enter the pratyekabuddha vehicle's nirvÄá¹‡a, those who are born
in the good destinies, and those who are born in the evil destinies.
The bodhisattva's wisdom is able to observe all of these. This is called the bodhisattva's wisdom observing the activities of all sentient beings.
What is meant by the wisdom of non-arising?
It means that the bodhisattva, in the four deportments of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, is completely without arising, yet the bodhisattva's wisdom naturally always turns.
It is like a person sleeping without any movement, yet the inhalation and exhalation naturally always turns;
the bodhisattva's wisdom is also like this, turning unobstructed in all places.
This is called the bodhisattva's wisdom of non-arising.
What is meant by the wisdom of knowing all dharmas?

That is to say, if a bodhisattva well knows the equal characteristics of all dharmas, the single characteristic, the various characteristics, the characteristics like an illusion, the characteristics of false discrimination, and so forth, and fully understands them as they really are, this is called the bodhisattva's knowledge of the characteristics of all dharmas.
What is supramundane knowledge?
That is to say, if a bodhisattva is endowed with uncontaminated knowledge, surpassing all mundane knowledge, this is called the bodhisattva's supramundane knowledge.
Good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, he will attain the perfection of all knowledge.
Moreover, good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates ten kinds of dharmas, he will attain the superior practices like the earth.
What are the ten?
First, like the earth, vast and immeasurable;
Second, sustaining all sentient beings;
Third, far removed from harm, benefiting and nurturing sentient beings equally;
Fourth, universally able to contain the great Dharma clouds and rain;
Fifth, being the common support for all sentient beings;
Sixth, being able to give rise to the seeds of good dharmas;
Seventh, being a great treasure vessel;
Eighth, being a great wondrous medicine;
Ninth, being unshakable;
Tenth, not giving rise to fear.
Good sons!
What is meant by being as vast and immeasurable as the earth?

Just as the great earth is vast and immeasurable, bodhisattvas are also like this, with their excellent practices of merit and wisdom vast and immeasurable, this is called bodhisattvas being as vast and immeasurable as the earth.
What is meant by sustaining all sentient beings?

It is like the great earth universally providing for all sentient beings, accepting and using the things they need. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the dharmas of giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, as well as the innumerable dharmas of bodhisattva practices, they are able to universally accept and transform sentient beings according to their needs. This is called bodhisattvas universally sustaining all sentient beings.
What is meant by 'avoiding harm and benefiting equally nurturing sentient beings'?

It is like the great earth, not distressed by harm and not delighted by benefit, without these two thoughts. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They are not distressed by the harm of sentient beings and not delighted by their benefits. They equally benefit and delight, without giving rise to joy or distress in any situation. This is called bodhisattvas avoiding harm and benefiting equally nurturing sentient beings.
What is meant by 'universally able to contain the great Dharma cloud and rain'?

It is like the great earth and great clouds containing moisture, all able to accommodate and support. Bodhisattvas are also like this. When the TathÄgata rises as a great cloud and rains down the great Dharma, he is able to accommodate and support everything as it is taught. This is called the bodhisattvas' all-encompassing accommodation of the Dharma cloud's rain.
What is meant by being the common support for all sentient beings?

It is like the great earth, all sentient beings, whether moving or still, all rely on the earth. Bodhisattvas are also like this. All sentient beings rely on the bodhisattvas, therefore they are born in the good destinies and head towards the path of nirvÄá¹‡a. This is called the bodhisattvas being the common support for all sentient beings.
What is meant by being able to give rise to the seeds of good dharmas?

It is like the great earth, all seeds are planted in the earth and grow from the earth. Bodhisattvas are also like this. All the seeds of good dharmas of sentient beings are all planted and grow from the bodhisattvas. This is called the bodhisattvas being able to give rise to the seeds of good dharmas.
What is meant by being a great treasure vessel?

It is like the great earth, which gives birth to various precious treasures. Therefore, the earth is a great treasure vessel. Bodhisattvas are also like this. Various merits and wisdom treasures are all manifested by bodhisattvas. Therefore, bodhisattvas are great treasure vessels. This is what is meant by bodhisattvas being great treasure vessels.
What is meant by being a great wondrous medicine?

It is like the great earth, which gives birth to all the various medicinal herbs in the world. They are able to cure various illnesses and sufferings. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They manifest the great Dharma medicine to universally cure the afflictive illnesses of all sentient beings in the world. This is what is meant by bodhisattvas being the great Dharma medicine.
What is meant by being unshakable?

It is like the great earth, which cannot be shaken by all the mosquitoes, gadflies, and other creatures born from moisture, or by the great wind. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They cannot be moved by any internal or external suffering or difficulties created by sentient beings. This is the bodhisattvas' unshakability.
What is meant by 'not giving rise to fear'?

It is like the great earth, where the roars and echoes of all the dragon kings and deer kings are heard without giving rise to fear. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They hear the voices of demons and non-Buddhists without giving rise to fear. This is the bodhisattvas' lack of fear.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the same as the earth.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the same as water.
What are the ten?
First, the flowing and moistening of good dharmas flows downward;
Second, planting the seeds of all good dharmas;
Third, it is to have faith, joy, and delight;
Fourth, it is to soak and destroy the roots of afflictions;
Fifth, it is to be pure without mixture in its own essence;
Sixth, it is to extinguish the raging flames of afflictions;
Seventh, it is to be able to stop all desires and cravings;
Eighth, it is to be deep and vast without limits;
Ninth, it is to be filled with highs and lows;
Tenth, it is to stop all the dust and dirt of afflictions.
What is meant by 'the good Dharma flowing down and filling up'?

Just as great water flows down and moistens and nourishes, so too are bodhisattvas. The good dharmas they cultivate flow down and moisten and nourish sentient beings. This is called the bodhisattvas' good Dharma flowing down and filling up, like water.
What is meant by 'planting the seeds of all good dharmas'?

It is like the great earth, which grows all trees, forests, and medicinal herbs, and causes them to increase and mature through the watering of water. Bodhisattvas are also like this. They extensively plant the seeds of all the factors of enlightenment. The water of concentration nourishes them again and again, causing them to increase until they become the tree of omniscience. Because this tree of omniscience is established, the fruits of various buddha-dharmas flourish, and they universally sustain the wisdom-life of all sentient beings. This is called bodhisattvas planting the seeds of various wholesome dharmas.
What is loving and joyfully believing?

It is like great water, whose nature is to flow and moisten itself and also to moisten others. Bodhisattvas are also like this. Their nature is to love, enjoy, and joyfully believe, and they are also able to cause all sentient beings to love, enjoy, and joyfully believe. Loving means delighting in seeking supramundane dharmas;
joyfully believing means believing in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha;
joyfully believing means the mind attaining purity. This is called bodhisattvas loving and joyfully believing.
What is meant by 'soaking and destroying the roots of afflictions'?

Just as the earth, trees, forests, and grasses are all soaked and destroyed by water, so too are the roots and seeds of afflictions of all sentient beings soaked by the water of the bodhisattvas' cultivation of meditative concentration, and because they are destroyed, the roots and seeds of afflictions do not continue to arise, and even the defiled habitual tendencies are all eliminated. This is called the bodhisattvas' soaking and destroying the roots of afflictions.
What is meant by 'the purity of the unmixed intrinsic nature'?

Just as great water has an unmixed intrinsic nature and is pure, so too are the bodhisattvas. The unmixed intrinsic nature is the fundamental nature of purity - the intrinsic nature refers to being free from the arising of secondary afflictions and so forth;
the unmixed refers to not being mixed with the dharmas of greed, anger, and delusion;
the purity refers to the extreme purity of guarding the faculties. This is called the bodhisattvas' purity of the unmixed intrinsic nature.
What is meant by 'extinguishing the blazing afflictions'?

It is like the earth being extremely hot in the summer months, and people also feeling hot and bothered. Water can remove and relieve all the heat and make them cool. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the water of the Dharma, they can extinguish the heat and suffering of afflictions that afflict the realms of all sentient beings. This is called the bodhisattvas' extinguishing the heat of afflictions.
What is meant by being able to stop all desires and cravings?

It is like worldly people who are oppressed by thirst and craving. Water can relieve them. Bodhisattvas are also like this. All sentient beings are oppressed by the thirst and craving for sense objects. Bodhisattvas rain down the great Dharma rain, completely relieving them and freeing them from all desires and cravings. This is called the bodhisattvas' being able to stop all desires and cravings.
What is meant by being deep and vast without limits?

It is like the great waters, with all the rivers coming together, being deep and vast without limits. Bodhisattvas are also like this. Their supreme wisdom accumulates, being deep and vast without limits. All demons and non-Buddhists are completely unable to fathom its depths. This is called the bodhisattvas' being deep and vast without limits.
What is meant by the high and low being filled?

It is like great water, unobstructed, flowing and filling all regions, although it is already full it does not harm any beings. Bodhisattvas are also like this, pouring down the great Dharma rain, universally moistening all the high and low of the realm of beings, although it is already full it does not harm any beings.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas have a mind of great compassion, this is called the bodhisattvas' Dharma rain flowing and filling the high and low.
What is meant by extinguishing all dust and defilement?

It is like great water moistening all the rough and evil regions covered by dust and defilement, causing them to be moistened and extinguishing all dust and defilement. Bodhisattvas are also like this, universally for all those with coarse and evil minds, causing them to give rise to a gentle mind, and then using the water of concentration and love based on supreme wisdom, moistening all beings and extinguishing all dust and defilement, this is called the bodhisattvas' extinguishing of the dust and defilement of afflictions.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of practices, they will attain the same as water.
Moreover, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the same as fire.
What are the ten?
First, they can burn the firewood of afflictions;
Second, they can ripen the Buddha-dharmas;
Third, they can dry up all the muddy waters of afflictions;
Fourth, they are like a great mass of fire;
Fifth, they can make radiant illumination;
Sixth, they can cause fear;
Seventh, they can provide comfort;
Eighth, they share the benefits they obtain with all sentient beings;
Ninth, they are revered by people;
Tenth, people do not look down on them.
Good man!
What is meant by 'they can burn the firewood of afflictions'?

It is like a great fire that can burn the earth, medicinal herbs, forests, and various other things. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the fire of wisdom, they can burn the greed, anger, and ignorance that arise, as well as the secondary afflictions. This is called bodhisattvas' ability to burn the firewood of afflictions.
What is meant by ripening the Buddha's teachings?

It is like a great fire that can ripen all kinds of seeds and medicines that grow in the earth. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the fire of wisdom, they can internally ripen all the Buddha's teachings. As they are ripened, they attain indestructibility. This is called bodhisattvas' ripening of the Buddha's teachings.
What is meant by being able to dry up the muddy waters of all afflictions?

It is like a great fire that can dry up all wet things and muddy waters. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the fire of wisdom, they can dry up all the muddy waters of afflictions. This is called bodhisattvas' ability to dry up the muddy waters of all afflictions.
What is meant by being like a great mass of fire?

It is like the various sentient beings suffering from cold who can be warmed by a great mass of fire. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the fire of wisdom, they can warm all sentient beings oppressed by the cold illness of afflictions. This is called a bodhisattva being like a great mass of fire.
What is illuminating with light?

It is like a person who lights a great mass of fire on the peak of the Snow Mountains or the peak of Mount Vindhya. The light of that fire universally illuminates for one yojana, or two or three yojanas, universally shining everywhere. Bodhisattvas are also like this. With the light of wisdom, they universally illuminate for one yojana, or a hundred or a thousand, up to immeasurable and innumerable worlds. The light of wisdom universally illuminates all sentient beings. Because the light of wisdom illuminates, all the ignorance and darkness of sentient beings is completely dispelled. This is called a bodhisattva illuminating with light.
What is causing fear?

It is like a great fire, all evil beasts or evil beast kings, seeing that fire, are all frightened and run away in the four directions, leaving their lairs. The great wisdom and virtue of the bodhisattva is also like this. If demons or gods see the bodhisattva, they all become frightened, abandon their own inferior and weak majestic light, leave that place far away, and never again hear the bodhisattva's name, let alone see his body.
This is the bodhisattva's ability to frighten.
What is comforting?

It is like a person who, in a vast wilderness and dangerous place, has lost their way. If they see a bonfire, they know there is a village or pasture nearby, and immediately go there, their mind at ease and free from all fear. Bodhisattvas are also like this. All sentient beings, dwelling in the dangerous places of birth and death, see the bodhisattvas and their minds are at ease, completely free from all the fears of afflictions. This is called the bodhisattvas' ability to bring comfort.
What is meant by sharing whatever benefits one obtains with all sentient beings?
It is like a great fire that is used by all sentient beings without distinction, whether they are kings, untouchables, or children. Bodhisattvas are also like this.

Whatever offerings and resources they obtain, they share them with all sentient beings without distinction, whether they are kings, untouchables, or children. This is called the bodhisattvas' sharing whatever benefits they obtain with all sentient beings.
What is meant by 'being worshipped by people'?

Just as worldly fires are all revered and worshipped by Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and commoners, bodhisattvas are also like this. All worldly beings, whether gods, humans, or asuras, all revere and make offerings to them, regarding them as buddhas. This is called 'being worshipped by people.'
What is meant by 'being unbelittled by people'?
Just as a small fire is not dared to be belittled by people.
Why is it so?
Because it can burn.

Bodhisattvas are also like this. If they abide in the stage of faith and practice, although bodhisattvas who have just begun to generate the mind in the Mahayana do not yet have the ability, worldly gods, humans, and asuras do not dare to belittle them.
Why is it so?

The devas, humans, and asuras know that this bodhisattva will soon sit at the site of enlightenment and attain the fruit of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. This is the bodhisattva's lack of contempt by others.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will then be like fire.
Moreover, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will then be like wind.
What are the ten?
First, like wind, they practice without obstruction;
Second, the realms they practice in are boundless;
Third, like wind, they disperse and destroy the lofty and arrogant mountains of sentient beings;
Fourth, they blow and spread the vast Dharma clouds and rain;
Fifth, they extinguish the blazing afflictions of all worldly beings;
Sixth, they do not move the good dharmas that sustain and nurture the lives of all sentient beings;
Seventh, immeasurable Dharma clouds contain moisture and uphold the great Dharma rain;
Eighth, because the various adornments of the great Dharma are arrayed in a marvelous manner in the pavilion;
Ninth, because all the assemblies are adorned with the trees of the eon, and the correct and wonderful Dharma sound always emerges, raining down delightful flowers;
